close_symbols: typedef/signature of response->crfc and functions that set response->crfc (e.g. creators that take free-callback)
explanation:
For deciding whether MHD_destroy_response violates the MISRA rule about out-of-bounds use of <string.h> routines, the missing information is how the memory being freed and the pointer members were produced and what their object sizes are. The listed symbols are required for that analysis:

- struct MHD_Response (definition): shows types and ownership semantics of fields accessed here (reference_count, mutex, crfc, crc_cls, data_iov, first_header). You must know exact types/ownership to determine whether any string.h calls elsewhere could have referenced these objects out-of-bounds or whether this function frees memory that was never/incorrectly allocated.

- struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header (definition): reveals types of pos->header, pos->value and pos->next and whether those pointers point to character buffers or other objects; needed to trace copies (strlen/strcpy/memcpy) done when headers/values were created.

- MHD_add_response_header: this routine is the central place other code uses to create/populate header/value pairs. It likely performs string operations (strdup/strcpy/strlen/memcpy). To judge bounds safety you must inspect how it allocates and copies data into header/value.

- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static / MHD_create_response_from_buffer / MHD_create_response_from_buffer_copy / MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback: these response constructors set up response->data_iov or internal buffers and may copy or reference user buffers using string/memory functions. They are the producers of the memory that destroy frees — inspect them for any string.h usage that could have produced an out-of-bounds pointer or mismatched length.

- MHD_create_response_from_callback, MHD_create_response_empty, MHD_create_response_from_fd64 / MHD_create_response_from_fd / MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset64 and iovec-based creators (MHD_create_response_from_iovec): other response-creation APIs visible in the call graph — they can allocate or point into buffers and may use string/memory functions. All creator variants must be checked to ensure buffers they provide are valid for any string.h calls done during their lifetime.

- create_response_object / create_response and init_response_body_data: project-specific initialisers that may allocate response objects, data_iov, or header/value buffers; you need their code to know how buffer sizes and ownership were set up.

- typedef/signature of response->crfc and functions that set it (e.g. creators that accept a free-callback): MHD_destroy_response invokes response->crfc(response->crc_cls). That callback may itself perform string.h operations on objects held by the response or the crc_cls argument. To be sure the overall sequence does not cause out-of-bounds accesses you must inspect the callback type and implementations that can be assigned here.

- definition/type of data_iov (iovec structure): response->data_iov is freed here. You must know whether it points to an array of iovecs, how many elements were allocated, and whether any earlier code (creators) used string/memory functions on those iovec buffers that could have been out-of-bounds.

In short: to determine any misuse of <string.h> that relates to the memory freed or passed through this function, you must inspect the structures and all allocation/initialisation routines that produce those buffers and any callbacks invoked here.
